Designboom. (2012). "bloom interactive pavilion by alisa andrasek + jose sanchez".

projects.title: Flight Assembled Architecture
projects.institutionOrPractice: ETH Zürich (Gramazio Kohler Research; Flying Machine Arena)
projects.summary: Flight Assembled Architecture is an experimental construction demonstrator in which autonomous quadrotors place discrete blocks to form a freestanding architectural-scale structure, foregrounding computation, coordination, and logistics as primary design media.
projects.analyticalCaption: The project reframes architectural form as an emergent consequence of multi-agent assembly constraints—payload capacity, collision avoidance, and spatial sequencing—thereby coupling geometry to a robotic process model rather than to static fabrication drawings.

computational: process-aware design (assembly sequencing and feasibility constraints)

images.alt: Overall view of the assembled tower produced by aerial placement of discrete blocks.
A quadrotor places a block onto the growing structure during aerial construction.
Two quadrotors fly in coordination to deliver and position blocks in parallel.

references.citation: ETH Zürich Flying Machine Arena. “Flight Assembled Architecture (FRAC Centre project page).”

projects.title: Flight Assembled Architecture
projects.institutionOrPractice: Gramazio Kohler Research, ETH Zurich & EPFL
projects.summary: A 6-meter-tall tower constructed from 1500 lightweight foam modules, assembled autonomously by four quadrotor drones during an exhibition. The project demonstrated a novel approach to construction in which flying robots collaboratively built an architectural structure by sequentially lifting and positioning discrete building blocks:contentReference[oaicite:0]{index=0}:contentReference[oaicite:1]{index=1}.
projects.analyticalCaption: Flight Assembled Architecture pioneered aerial robotic assembly in architecture. Its stackable foam units and autonomous drone builders illustrated the potential of discrete, additive construction systems that can scale to architectural dimensions:contentReference[oaicite:2]{index=2}:contentReference[oaicite:3]{index=3}. This project provided a proof-of-concept for combinatorial design freed from ground-based construction constraints.

images.alt: Quadcopter drone placing a foam block during Flight Assembled Architecture.
Completed 6m foam block tower built by flying robots at FRAC Centre.
Diagram of drone assembly process for Flight Assembled Architecture installation.

references.citation: Gramazio, F.; Kohler, M.; D'Andrea, R. (2011). “Flight Assembled Architecture” – FRAC Centre installation description.

projects.title: ICD/ITKE Research Pavilion 2011
projects.summary: A temporary pavilion constructed from 500 segmented timber plates that were custom cut to interlock like a giant 3D puzzle. Inspired by the exoskeleton of sand dollars, the pavilion formed a convex shell approximately 10 meters across. Each plate was unique, CNC-milled from birch plywood with tongue-and-groove edges so that when assembled with adjacent plates, they achieved a double-curved surface without additional framing. The assembly was done by students who pieced the segments together in situ, aided by formwork and cable ties which were later removed. The resulting structure was self-supporting, demonstrating how non-identical, discrete elements can assemble into a continuous, doubly curved architecture through high-precision fabrication and design computation:contentReference[oaicite:132]{index=132}:contentReference[oaicite:133]{index=133}.
projects.analyticalCaption: The ICD/ITKE 2011 Pavilion was a landmark in showing that complex free-form geometries can be constructed from purely discrete parts. It translated a biological reference (the segmented plates of a sand dollar) into an architectural strategy: many thin plates, each optimized in shape, collectively bearing loads through geometric locking:contentReference[oaicite:134]{index=134}. Crucially, the pavilion used no glue or nails at the plate joints — it relied on carefully designed friction-fit connections and the overall shell action for stability. This project prefigured later developments in segmented shells and digital timber; it validated that with computational design for shape and robotic fabrication for accuracy, even highly irregular forms can be realized via the discrete assembly paradigm.

assemblyFabrication: manual interlocking assembly with temporary ties

images.alt: ICD/ITKE Research Pavilion 2011: a wooden shell structure composed of many interlocking polygonal plates.
Interior view of the 2011 pavilion, showing the network of interlocking plate seams with no additional support beneath.
Assembly model of pavilion segments: a cluster of curved plywood pieces that fit together like a puzzle, with labeling for assembly sequence.

references.citation: Dörstelmann, M., et al. (2013). "Design, simulation and implementation of segmented wood shell structures" – Journal of the International Association for Shell and Spatial Structures, 54(4).
ArchDaily. (2012). "ICD | ITKE Research Pavilion 2011" – project description.

projects.title: OpenStructures
projects.summary: OpenStructures (OS) is an ongoing collaborative project proposing a universal construction grid so that parts designed by anyone can fit with parts designed by others. It is based on a single geometric framework: a grid where 4cm x 4cm squares form the basic unit (with a 1cm division), allowing creation of components that consistently align and connect. Since 2011, designers around the world have contributed OS-compatible designs – from furniture and lighting to small architectural installations. For example, an OS pavilion displayed in 2012 used standardized connectors and panels, each contributed by different designers, assembled into a cohesive structure. The concept is akin to a grown-up LEGO or Meccano set, but open-source: all designs are published so that a global library of modular components can emerge, enabling circular reuse and mix-and-match assembly across projects:contentReference[oaicite:118]{index=118}.
projects.analyticalCaption: OpenStructures shifts the focus from individual projects to the ecosystem of parts underlying them. It asks: what if all our objects and buildings shared a common interface? This meta-project argues that by agreeing on a discrete grid and connection standards, design becomes a collaborative, evolutionary process, much like open-source software. In an architectural context, OS suggests that buildings could be composed of interoperable modules sourced from a marketplace of creators, breaking down silos between manufacturers. Although still largely conceptual and at small scales, OpenStructures is an important cultural project that pushes discrete architecture beyond proprietary systems towards an open, participatory model where everyone designs pieces of a larger puzzle and those pieces can be recombined infinitely in new creations:contentReference[oaicite:120]{index=120}.

images.alt: Diagram of the OpenStructures grid: a pattern of 4x4 cm squares subdivided, illustrating the modular base for part design.
An experimental pavilion built with OpenStructures components: various panels and connectors in a grid-based frame.
Collection of OpenStructures parts contributed by different designers: colorful panels, connectors, and mechanisms all following the OS grid standard.

references.citation: Lommée, T. (2012). "OpenStructures: Towards a open-source modular system" – in Product Design: Challenging the Future.
OpenStructures. (2021). OpenStructures Platform – project overview and library.

projects.title: WikiHouse (Open-Source Digital Construction System)
projects.projectType: open-source kit-of-parts platform for digitally fabricated buildings
projects.summary: WikiHouse is an open-source platform for the design and fabrication of discrete building components that can be digitally manufactured and assembled into architectural structures, emphasizing accessibility, modularity, and iterative improvement through shared standards.
projects.analyticalCaption: The system operationalizes a digital-to-physical pipeline in which component geometry encodes assembly constraints, enabling distributed production and enabling buildings to be conceived as recombinable inventories rather than monolithic constructions.

assemblyFabrication: dry assembly enabling disassembly and reuse

images.alt: WikiHouse structure photographed in use as an assembled prototype/building system example.
WikiHouse at The Hub Westminster, showing the assembled timber kit structure.
Detail view of WikiHouse elements, emphasizing component articulation and jointing logic (ViennaOpen 2015 context).

references.citation: Wikipedia contributors. “WikiHouse.”

projects.title: GC Prostho Museum (Chidori Architecture)
projects.summary: A museum whose interior is defined by an extensive interlocking wood lattice inspired by a traditional Japanese toy called 'Chidori'. Completed in 2010, the GC Prostho Museum features thousands of small wooden sticks with unique notched joints that connect without nails or glue. These units form a self-supporting 3D grid that flows seamlessly from ceiling to walls, demonstrating how a simple modular element can generate a complex spatial experience. The assembly was achieved by carefully twisting and slotting each timber element in place, resulting in a reversible, puzzle-like construction:contentReference[oaicite:53]{index=53}:contentReference[oaicite:54]{index=54}.
projects.analyticalCaption: Kuma’s design for the Prostho Museum reinvents vernacular joinery as a discrete architectural system. The chidori lattice comprises repetitive timber components that achieve rigidity through geometric locking alone:contentReference[oaicite:55]{index=55}:contentReference[oaicite:56]{index=56}. This project exemplifies a fusion of craft and digital design: while rooted in a pre-digital module, it was realized through precise computation of each joint. The outcome is a richly textured environment that illustrates how non-metallic, interlocking kits-of-parts can scale to architectural structures and be assembled or dismantled in situ.

images.alt: Interior view of GC Prostho Museum's interlocking wooden lattice ceiling.
Close-up of Chidori joint: wooden sticks with unique cuts interpenetrating at right angles.
Diagram of Chidori joint module showing the shape of the wooden element and how rotation locks it with others.

references.citation: Detail Magazine. (2012). “GC Prostho Museum by Kengo Kuma” – project analysis.
Stir World. (2020). “Tradition and Technique – Chidori furniture by Kengo Kuma” (on Chidori system).

projects.title: GC Prostho Museum Research Center
projects.summary: The GC Prostho Museum Research Center translates the logic of the traditional Japanese Cidori (Chidori) toy into a building-scale timber lattice, constructing architectural space through the repetition and combination of small interlocking units without metal fasteners.
projects.analyticalCaption: By scaling a discrete joint grammar into an inhabitable system, the project exemplifies combinatorial architecture in which structural capacity, enclosure, and display infrastructure emerge from a unified unit-based assembly logic.

computational: coordination of repetition and variation within a discrete lattice
assemblyFabrication: manual assembly of interlocking timber members
fastener-free joinery logic (no nails/metal fittings in the Cidori principle)

images.alt: Overall view of the GC Prostho Museum Research Center lattice structure.
Interior view emphasizing the spatial density and visual porosity of the timber grid.
Elevation/diagrammatic representation associated with the building’s lattice system.

projects.title: Nakagin Capsule Tower
projects.summary: An iconic 13-story tower composed of 140 removable prefabricated micro-apartments (capsules) attached to two concrete cores. Each capsule (measuring 2.5m x 4m) was a fully outfitted living unit manufactured off-site and fastened to the core with only four high-tension bolts, theoretically allowing replacement or reconfiguration over time. The Nakagin Capsule Tower embodied the Metabolist vision of growable architecture, although in practice the capsules were never swapped out before the building’s demolition in 2022:contentReference[oaicite:57]{index=57}:contentReference[oaicite:58]{index=58}.
projects.analyticalCaption: Nakagin Capsule Tower pioneered discrete combinatorial architecture at an urban housing scale. It treated dwelling units as interchangeable parts — a radical departure from static construction:contentReference[oaicite:59]{index=59}. This design decoupled individual habitations from the structural core, foreshadowing later kit-of-parts strategies. While its plug-in scheme remained largely aspirational due to maintenance challenges, Nakagin’s striking realization of modularity and temporality has influenced generations of architects exploring flexibility and mass-customization in architecture.

images.alt: Nakagin Capsule Tower exterior in 2010, showing many small cubic capsules cantilevered from a central shaft.
Interior of a Nakagin capsule apartment, demonstrating the compact prefabricated living space.
Diagram illustrating how individual capsule units attach to the Nakagin Tower's core with bolts.

references.citation: Kurokawa, K. (1977). Metabolism in Architecture. Studio Vista.
MoMA. (2022). "The Many Lives of the Nakagin Capsule Tower" – exhibition (preservation of capsule).

projects.title: Habitat 67
projects.summary: A landmark housing project originally built as part of Expo 67, consisting of 354 identical precast concrete boxes assembled into 158 apartments. Habitat 67’s modules (approximately 12m x 6m each) are stacked in varied geometries up to 12 stories high, creating interlocking terraces and bridges. The design aimed to combine the privacy and garden access of suburban homes with the density of an apartment building. Each prefabricated box was factory-made and then arranged on-site using cranes, demonstrating early ambitions for mass-produced modular urban housing:contentReference[oaicite:60]{index=60}:contentReference[oaicite:61]{index=61}.
projects.analyticalCaption: Habitat 67 is a seminal example of combinatorial architecture in large-scale housing. It treats the dwelling unit as a standardized building block that can be aggregated in multiple configurations, yielding a complex yet holistic structure:contentReference[oaicite:62]{index=62}. The project anticipated later kit-of-parts thinking by addressing repetitive manufacturing, on-site assembly efficiencies, and resident customization (through varied module arrangements). Decades on, Habitat 67 remains a persuasive built argument for prefabrication’s role in humanizing high-density housing through spatial diversity derived from discrete modules.

images.alt: Habitat 67 complex showing stacked concrete boxes with terraces in Montreal.
Close-up of Habitat 67 modules highlighting the connections and outdoor terraces formed between units.
Architectural model of Habitat 67 demonstrating the modular concept and possible configurations of the boxes.

references.citation: Safdie, M. (1970). Beyond Habitat. MIT Press.
Tomorrow City. (2021). “Habitat 67: a brutalist icon where suburban home meets urban density”.
